articles.title: Economy plummets from computerized trading
articles.body: A positive feedback loop involving high-frequency trading algorithms went uncaught for 32 seconds and has devastated markets worldwide. Millions have gone bankrupt and companies' share values are plummeting. Economists anticipate effects worsening with millions more expected to lose employment after companies seek to cut costs.

articles.title: Economic progress stutters
articles.body: Toxic financial assets have been stretched too far. Hundreds of thousands have lost life savings due to common but ethically-ambiguous practices.

articles.title: Economy is doing ok
articles.body: To the givers of this beautiful reward, my thanks, from the heart. My family, my agents, my editors, know that my being here is their doing as well as my own, and that the beautiful reward is theirs as much as mine.

articles.title: New growth records reached
articles.body: The economy has been experiencing unprecedented growth. Consumers feel more comfortable than ever borrowing money from credit lenders - expect consumer spending to go up, up, up!

articles.body: New study finds that {{formatCurrencyAbbrev debtOwned}} of consumer debt is owned by {{name}}.

articles.title: Pollution too high, EPA finds
articles.body: The EPA reports that {{pollution}} metric tons of pollution are due to {{name}}'s activities.

articles.title: Earth in "bad shape", study shows
articles.body: Climate change is finally catching up with us. Freshwater supplies and other vital natural resources have decreased irreversibly, reports 20-year long study published today.

articles.title: Death is good business
articles.body: A UN commission investigating {{name}} estimates that its products are responsible for at least {{deathToll}} deaths around the world.

articles.title: Mass Protests Against Defense Contractor
articles.body: There were massive protests today outside the headquarters of {{name}}, a prominent defense contractor who's advanced weapons designed for state and private militaries alike have caused over an estimated {{deathToll}} deaths worldwide.

articles.title: Wage protests spread
articles.body: Protests flare up internationally against the {{formatCurrency globalAvgWage}} minimum wage.

articles.title: Consumer spending reaches records
articles.body: Consumer spending has reached {{consumerSpending}}% their previous levels. "There are so many lifestyle brands that speak to me," chirped one consumer. "I just can't help myself!"

articles.title: Journalism unimportant?
articles.body: A media study finds that {{forgettingRate}} of the population is disinterested in journalism.

articles.title: Decreasing attention spans, study finds
articles.body: A new report suggests that attention spans have plunged in the past decade. "Most consumers forget what they were reading or talking about by the next day. Outrage is unsustainable nowadays," said one of the researchers.

articles.title: Dire growth for {{name}}
articles.body: {{name}} fell way behind expectations this quarter, with sales contracting by a dangerous amount. Investor confidence is at an all-time low as rumors about a change in leadership are abound.

articles.title: Disappointing growth for {{name}}
articles.body: {{name}} disappointed shareholders this quarter, falling short of analysts' predictions this quarter. The share price took a tumble in the wake of the earnings announcement.

articles.title: Astounding growth for {{name}}
articles.body: {{name}} had an extraordinary quarter, expanding revenue well beyond expectations. Consumers are diehard about the brand - they can't get enough of {{name}}'s products.

articles.title: Excellent growth for {{name}}
articles.body: {{name}} beat analysts' predictions this quarter, expanding revenue more than expected. Investors, keep your eye on {{name}}.
